Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Integrating Molecular Mechanisms and Quantitative Genetics in Order to Understand Consistent Individual Differences in Behavior; Urbana, IL; Summer, 2016
Award.AbstractNarration: Within the study of animal behavior questions remain concerning why population variation in behaviors exist, why individuals sometimes show consistent behavior across time while at other times they do not, and last why we see certain behaviors occurring together within individuals, or the expression of animal personalities. Behavior is controlled by genes and there are a number of ways in which researchers can ask questions about behavior and the genes that control their expression. However some of our most valuable investigative techniques, and the data they produce, are not easily integrated. This is a significant missing piece to our full understanding of how genes control behaviors. Here a workshop will bring together researchers from a wide variety of areas within behavior and genetics to address this missing integration to determine how data can be brought together and develop training plans and recommendations for current and future researchers in the area of genetics and behavior. Outcomes from this workshop will be broadly disseminated to the scientific community through publications and are of benefit not only to the behavioral sciences but to studies of ecology, evolution, neuroscience, and physiology - including human health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A general challenge for biology in the genomics era is to integrate genomic data within existing conceptual frameworks such as quantitative genetics. The challenge is particularly acute for traits such as behavioral traits that can both vary among individuals and which can also change within individuals, i.e. which are plastic. To address these challenges, a workshop tasked with integrating molecular mechanisms into quantitative genetics in order to understand consistent individual differences in behavior was convened between July 23-27, 2016 at the Carl R. Woese Institute for Genomic Biology at the University of Illinois, Urbana Champaign. The overarching goal of the workshop was to develop new theory, methods and applications for integrating molecular mechanisms into quantitative genetics in order to understand consistent individual differences in behavior.  

Eighteen researchers from the U.S., Canada and Europe convened for three days to tackle six main challenges for integrating that were identified by the conference organizers. Participants in this workshop comprised a diverse group of scientists from a variety of backgrounds and institutions. Particants included 8 women (out of 18), one participant from a primarily undergraduate-serving institution, and 6 pretenure scientists (or equivalent). Considerable headway was made during the workshop through discussion, collaboration and writing. At the end of the workshop, participants had detailed outlines for six manuscripts. 

In addition to the invited participats in the workshop, two graduate students and one postdoc at the Univesrity of Illinois participanted in the workshop and will be co-authors on at least one of the resulting papers. In addition, the workshop offered networking and careeer building opportunities for 6 pre-tenure participants in the workshop. An important product of the workshop is a paper explicitly devoted to articulating the types of training and opportunities available to young scientists in this dynamic area of research. 

The end result of the workshop is series of papers that: (1) Identifies conceptual, statistical and empirical gaps between quantitative genetics and molecular mechanisms, as applied to consistent individual differences in behavior (a list of the topics is below); (2) Fills in the gaps with theory or statistics for integration; (3) Articulates the specific areas in need of further statistical, theoretical and empirical investigation; (4) Identifies the types of training that are needed to accomplish the integration. This integration exemplifies the type of challenge required to move the study of Animal Behavior forward, as recently suggested by the NSF White Paper on New Frontiers for the Integrative Study of Animal Behavior. This group made tangible conceptual advances, and articulated an agenda to guide research into the future.
